questions.text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his girlfriend because of a 12-hour history of agitation and bizarre behavior. The girlfriend reports that, over the past 3 months, the patient has become withdrawn and stopped pursuing hobbies that he used to enjoy. Around that time, he started to become apprehensive about leaving his apartment and began to express suspicions that the FBI was trying to control his mind. One month ago, he lost his job because he stopped going to work to avoid being spied on. He used to smoke cannabis occasionally in high school but quit 5 years ago. Physical and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he is confused and suspicious with marked psychomotor agitation. His speech is disorganized and his affect is labile. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder requires that patients meet the criteria for a mood disorder (major depressive episode or manic episode) while exhibiting psychotic symptoms consistent with schizophrenia. In addition, psychotic symptoms must be present in the absence of mood disorder symptoms for at least 2 weeks. This patient does not meet the criteria for a mood disorder episode.

B) INCORRECT:

Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by psychotic symptoms lasting > 1 day but ≤ 1 month and is usually triggered by stressful situations. This patient's symptoms began three months ago.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient shows signs of social withdrawal, a preference for solitary activities, and reduced affect, which are all features of schizoid personality disorder. However, personality disorders are pervasive, inflexible, and maladaptive personality patterns that arise during adolescence, lead to distress or impairment, and are stable over time. Individuals with schizoid personality disorder generally do not have the desire for close relationships. They show little interest in interpersonal or sexual contact and often appear indifferent or emotionally cold towards others. This diagnosis is unlikely given the fact that he has a girlfriend and developed symptoms three months ago.

D) INCORRECT:

A number of prescription drugs (e.g., benzodiazepines) and illicit drugs (cannabis, alcohol) can cause substance-induced psychotic disorder. Symptoms generally occur during or shortly after exposure, intoxication, or withdrawal. There is no evidence of current substance abuse in this patient, making this diagnosis unlikely. Frequent use of cannabis is, however, associated with an increased risk of psychosis and schizophrenia.

E) INCORRECT:

Paranoid personality disorder, like all personality disorders, is a pervasive, inflexible, and maladaptive personality pattern that arises during adolescence, leads to distress or impairment and is stable over time. Patients tend to be suspicious of other people's intentions, often reading hidden meaning or threats into benign events, and do not confide in others for fear of being deceived or exploited. This diagnosis is unlikely in this patient given the fact that he developed symptoms three months ago.

F) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's clinical presentation is consistent with schizophrenia, symptoms must cause social, occupational, or personal functional impairment lasting ≥ 6 months for this diagnosis.

G) CORRECT:

Schizophreniform disorder is a clinical diagnosis that is made using the same diagnostic criteria as schizophrenia. The main difference, however, is the duration of the disorder. Schizophreniform disorder is diagnosed in patients who present with delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, and/or negative symptoms that impair social, occupational, and personal functioning over a period of 1–6 months (see “Psychotic disorders” table). If symptoms persist for ≥ 6 months, the diagnosis must be changed to schizophrenia. About one-third of patients recover, while the other two-thirds go on to develop schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder.

H) INCORRECT:

Schizotypal personality disorder, like all personality disorders, is a pervasive, inflexible, and maladaptive personality pattern that arises during adolescence, leads to distress or impairment and is stable over time. Patients typically exhibit odd, eccentric behavior and describe unusual beliefs and experiences. They may express suspicion of other people's intentions, and social and interpersonal interactions usually cause them discomfort. Psychotic symptoms would not be expected.

I) INCORRECT:

Although this patient exhibits signs consistent with delusional disorder (e.g., delusions, paranoia), he also has other symptoms that affect his social and occupational functioning, including disorganized speech and behavior, social withdrawal, and anhedonia. Delusional disorder is therefore an unlikely diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with acute agitation, disorganized speech, and bizarre behavior following a 3-month history of delusions, social withdrawal, and anhedonia that affected his social and occupational functioning.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a change in his personality. The mother reports that over the past 7 months her son has become increasingly withdrawn; he has not answered any phone calls or visited his family and friends. He had always been a quiet boy, who needed some time on his own, but he used to meet with friends at least once a week. The patient says that he cannot leave the house because aliens are watching him and are “stealing his thoughts”. He does not drink alcohol. He used to smoke cannabis occasionally but quit 1 year ago. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, it is impossible to follow the patient's sequence of thoughts. He is anxious and has a flat affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although brief psychotic disorder can cause symptoms similar to those seen in this patient, it can only be diagnosed if symptoms persist for > 1 day but ≤ 1 month. This patient's symptoms started 7 months ago.

B) INCORRECT:

Schizotypal personality disorder is also characterized by eccentric behavior, which may include magical thinking (e.g., inventing causal relationships between unrelated events). However, such thinking is rarely of the bizarre type. Furthermore, negative symptoms such as social withdrawal, agitation, and fleeting thoughts are less severe than those seen in this patient. Additionally, personality disorders are stable over time, whereas this patient's symptoms started only 7 months ago.

C) INCORRECT:

Delusional disorder does not cause significant functional impairment, whereas this patient has been unable to leave his house for fear of aliens watching his thoughts. These kinds of thoughts are also inconsistent with the usually nonbizarre delusions in delusional disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Mood disorder with psychotic features would require a diagnosis of mania or major depressive disorder (MDD). Although flat affect and social withdrawal can also be seen in MDD, this patient exhibits no feelings of worthlessness or guilt, depressed mood, suicidal ideation, weight change due to appetite change or sleep disturbances. As such, he does not meet enough of the criteria for a diagnosis of MDD.

E) INCORRECT:

Schizoaffective disorder can cause symptoms similar to those seen in this patient. However, the diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder requires a major mood disorder (e.g., major depressive disorder; MDD) to be present. Even though flat affect and social withdrawal can also be seen in MDD, this patient exhibits no feelings of worthlessness or guilt, depressed mood, suicidal ideation, weight change due to appetite change or sleep disturbances. As such, he does not meet enough of the criteria for a diagnosis of MDD.

F) INCORRECT:

Although paranoid personality disorder is also characterized by excessive suspicions and paranoia, such suspicion derives from a distrust of others rather than long-standing bizarre delusions such as aliens stealing thoughts. Additionally, personality disorders are stable over time, whereas this patient's symptoms started only 7 months ago.

G) INCORRECT:

Substance-induced psychosis (e.g., from cannabis use) can also manifest with bizarre behavior, delusions, and a state of anxiety or agitation, as seen in this patient. However, this patient stopped smoking cannabis a year ago and does not report using any other substance that could result in substance-induced psychosis.

H) INCORRECT:

Schizophreniform disorder is an important differential diagnosis as the symptoms are the same as in this patient. But schizophreniform disorder can only be diagnosed if the symptoms have not been present for longer than 6 months. This patient's symptoms began 7 months ago.

I) INCORRECT:

Schizoid personality disorder is also characterized by odd and eccentric behavior, flat affect, and social withdrawal. But these features are not as severe as in this patient (has not left the house for fear of aliens watching his thoughts). Additionally, personality disorders are stable over time, whereas this patient's symptoms started only 7 months ago.

J) CORRECT:

Schizophrenia typically manifests with a prodrome of negative symptoms (e.g., social withdrawal, flat affect) that precedes the positive psychotic symptoms, such as delusions (e.g., bizarre thoughts of aliens watching him) and disorganized speech. The diagnosis also requires that these symptoms have been present for ≥ 1 month and that some sign of illness must persist for at least 6 months.
questions.hint: Frequent use of cannabis during adolescence is a possible trigger for this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male graduate student comes to the physician for a 2-month history of repetitive thoughts and anxiety that he is going to be harmed by a stranger on the street. The anxiety worsened after witnessing a pedestrian getting hit by a car 2 weeks ago. He says, “That was a warning sign.” On his way to school, he often leaves an hour early to take a detour and hide from people who he believes might hurt him. He says his friends are concerned about him but that they do not understand because they were not present at the accident. He reports no decline in academic performance. The patient has no known history of psychiatric illness. On mental status examination, he is alert and oriented, and shows full range of affect. Thought processes and speech are organized. His memory and attention are intact. He denies auditory, visual, or tactile hallucinations. Urine toxicology screening is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with avoidant personality disorder may develop anxiety that is due to a fear of criticism, disapproval, or rejection. These individuals also have low self-esteem and have trouble with personal relationships resulting from feelings of personal inadequacy or inferiority. Avoiding people on the street out of fear of bodily harm is not consistent with an avoidant personality disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

A patient with schizotypal personality disorder may be suspicious, anxious, and have ideas of reference (e.g., believing that a witnessed traffic accident has personal significance). However, the anxiety in schizotypal personality disorder is usually provoked by social interactions rather than by fear of bodily harm. Moreover, other features of this personality disorder such as having few friends, an oddly dressed appearance, magical beliefs that are inconsistent with cultural norms, and a restricted affect are not present in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Delusional disorder is characterized by the presence of one or more delusions that last ≥ 1 month with no other psychotic symptoms (e.g., prominent hallucinations, disorganized thoughts and/or speech, negative symptoms of schizophrenia) or harmful substance use. Individuals with delusional disorder may also experience ideas of reference (e.g., believing that a witnessed traffic accident has personal significance) as well as nonprominent hallucinations that are thematically related to their delusion. Unlike individuals with schizophrenia and schizophreniform disorder, patients with delusional disorder show no significant functional impairment and do not have an odd appearance apart from their delusions and related behaviors.

D) INCORRECT:

Although patients with schizophreniform disorder may have delusions, such delusions are typically bizarre (i.e., clearly implausible, not derived from ordinary life experiences, and/or not understandable). Moreover, other features such as auditory hallucinations, disorganized speech, a flattened affect, and catatonia are seen with schizophreniform disorder.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) may develop anxiety about various issues (e.g., fear of being involved in an accident). However, GAD is not associated with ideas of reference or delusions. Moreover, GAD often results in somatic symptoms such as fatigue, irritability, insomnia, or muscle tension, and the symptoms of anxiety must be present for ≥ 6 months before GAD can be diagnosed.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with schizoid personality disorder are voluntarily reclusive, indifferent to praise or criticism, and have a flattened affect. Anxiety that stems from the fear of bodily harm, the presence of a circle of friends, and a full range of affect rule out the diagnosis of schizoid personality disorder.
questions.hint: This patient's fixed belief that he is going to be harmed by a stranger on the street has led to odd behavior (e.g., taking a one-hour detour to school) but no significant functional impairment.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by the police after she was found yelling at a bookshelf in a public library 30 minutes ago. The patient appears unkempt and restless. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. On mental status examination, she talks very fast with occasional abrupt interruptions and frequent changes of topic. She is cooperative but requires continuous redirection. She is disoriented to time and repeatedly tells the physician, “I hear the sun telling me that I was chosen to save the universe.” The remainder of the examination, including cardiopulmonary and neurological examination, shows no abnormalities. The results of routine serum studies show no abnormalities and urine toxicology screening is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An antipsychotic such as haloperidol is used as a calming medication for patients who are suspected to be agitated as a result of psychosis but parenteral administration is only required for patients who are uncooperative or severely agitated. Intravenous administration of a high-potency typical antipsychotic such as haloperidol is typically a measure of last resort because of the high risk for certain acute adverse events (e.g., QT prolongation, acute dystonic reaction).

B) INCORRECT:

Short- or intermediate-acting benzodiazepines (e.g., midazolam, lorazepam) are the first-line calming medication for patients with undifferentiated agitation or agitation due to alcohol withdrawal, benzodiazepine withdrawal, or CNS stimulant toxicity. For patients with psychosis from psychiatric illness, benzodiazepines are only used as an adjunct when the patient is severely agitated or violent.

C) INCORRECT:

Ketamine, a commonly used sedative in the emergency department, is only indicated if the patient is severely agitated or violent. Ketamine is also typically avoided in patients who are suspected to have a psychotic disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid, a mood stabilizer, is used for maintenance therapy in patients with bipolar disorder. Although this patient has features that could also be consistent with a manic episode (e.g., flight of ideas, pressured speech), mood stabilizers are ineffective in the acute management of agitation.

E) CORRECT:

An antipsychotic (e.g., risperidone, ziprasidone, haloperidol) is the appropriate calming medication for patients with psychosis. It is appropriate to ask the patients who are cooperative and only mildly agitated to voluntarily take the medication orally. Despite a slower onset of action, oral medications are as effective as parenteral medication and offer the patient a sense of control. Parenteral administration is only required for patients who are uncooperative or severely agitated. The use of force (e.g., involuntary sedation) should only be considered if all other measures fail or if the patient is actively violent.
questions.hint: Auditory hallucinations without a positive toxicology screening or features to suggest an organic medical disease indicate that patient has psychosis due to psychiatric disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with her 17-year-old son because she believes she has been poisoned by her ex-husband. She reports that her coffee tasted “strange” this morning. After breakfast, she then saw a black car drive by the house, which she concludes must have been her ex-husband, who also drives a black car. She says that since the divorce 3 years ago, her ex-husband has been seeking revenge and thinks that he has installed cameras in her apartment to spy on her and their son. She has never seen any of these cameras but when she is alone in the apartment, she can sometimes hear them beeping and feel them recording her. The son also reports his mother's coffee mug smelled of bitter almonds, which he suspects was cyanide. He agrees with the mother's distrust towards his father and reports that he has also occasionally heard a camera beeping but has not been able to find any cameras yet. The mother's vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows a pH of 7.4. Toxicology screening is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Report the case to the police authorities

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ziprasidone is a first-line agent for the treatment of shared psychotic disorder. However, before beginning pharmacotherapy, the degree of delusion of mother and son should be assessed to determine whether pharmacotherapy is indicated and, if so, what agents are best suited for the treatment of these patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluphenazine is a very potent typical antipsychotic but is not a first-line drug in patients with shared psychotic disorder because of its possible extrapyramidal motor symptoms (e.g., dystonia). Before initiating pharmacotherapy, another measure is indicated here.

C) CORRECT:

When delusional symptoms are suspected in an individual who has a relationship with someone with prominent delusions, they should be separated and assessed individually to determine the degree of delusion in each patient and evaluate the necessity for further interventions. Treatment includes individual psychotherapy (e.g., cognitive-behavioral therapy), second-generation antipsychotics for both patients and, if possible and/or necessary, spatial separation of the two.

D) INCORRECT:

While there are difficulties within this family (e.g., divorce, dysfunctional relationships), family therapy is not indicated here because it would likely reinforce the shared delusions rather than resolve them.

E) INCORRECT:

Cognitive-behavioral therapy can be helpful in treating patients with delusional disorders who refuse to take or cannot tolerate antipsychotics. It can help identify and engage the source of the delusions as well as manage the distress associated with them. However, before beginning any form of treatment, another measure is indicated here.

F) INCORRECT:

The fact that toxicology screening was negative rules out cyanide poisoning and suggests that this woman's report was imaginary. While reports of abuse or threats should never be dismissed lightly, the rest of this patient's report supports the suspicion of delusion rather than indicating that an actual crime has been committed. This warrants assessment for a mental disorder before considering legal measures.
questions.hint: This patient presents with persecutory delusions as well as auditory hallucinations, which are symptoms of psychosis. The patient's son shows delusional symptoms in the context of a relationship with an individual with prominent delusions (formerly known as shared psychotic disorder).

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her father because of a change in her behavior over the past 8 months. The father says that his daughter has become increasingly withdrawn; she has not answered any phone calls or visited her family and friends. The patient says that she has to stay at home because a foreign intelligence service is monitoring her. She thinks that they are using a magnetic field to read her mind. Mental status exam shows disjointed and perseverative thinking. She is anxious and has a flat affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Schizophrenia commonly presents with a prodrome of negative symptoms (e.g., disorganized thinking, social withdrawal), followed by positive symptoms (e.g., hallucinations, delusions, bizarre behavior). The diagnosis requires that these symptoms have been present for ≥ 1 month and that some sign of illness has persisted for at least 6 months. Based on this patient's symptoms of social withdrawal and paranoid delusion, which have been present for around 8 months, she has schizophrenia.

B) INCORRECT:

Delusional disorder is characterized by fixed, odd beliefs that are not consistent with cultural norms. This patient's functional impairment (e.g., staying at home, avoiding family and friends) is not consistent with delusional disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Paranoid personality disorder is characterized by irrational distrust towards others and the misconception that other people have malicious intentions. However, this woman has evidence of paranoid delusions (e.g., she's convinced she's being monitored using a magnetic field) and disorganized thought process, neither of which are characteristic of paranoid personality disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Schizoid personality disorder is also characterized by odd and eccentric behavior, flat affect, and a lack of close friendships. However, this patient's severe social withdrawal and paranoid delusions are not typical of schizoid personality disorder. Additionally, personality disorders typically begin in early adulthood and remain stable over time, while the onset of this patient's symptoms was fairly recent.

E) INCORRECT:

Schizophreniform disorder is an important diagnosis to consider in this patient, as it can also present with paranoid delusions and social withdrawal. However, schizophreniform disorder is only diagnosed if the symptoms have been present for less than 6 months.
questions.hint: Patients with this disease can also develop catatonia.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her boyfriend because of a 4-month history of feeling sad. Her boyfriend says that, during this period, she has slept and eaten very little and has been unable to focus at work. She says that she feels “empty inside” and has been hearing voices telling her that she is worthless. She first heard these voices 7 months ago when they started to make fun of her. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Physical and neurological examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, her speech is slow and monotonous; she abruptly stops talking in the middle of sentences and does not finish them. She occasionally directs her attention to the ceiling as if she were listening to someone. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has auditory hallucinations that started 7 months ago and disorganized speech (thought-blocking; stopping in the middle of sentences), which fulfills the criteria for schizophrenia. However, with the addition of her mood symptoms, she meets the criteria for another psychiatric diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Schizophreniform disorder is characterized by psychotic symptoms that last 1–6 months. This patient's psychotic symptoms started 7 months ago when she first started hearing voices.

C) INCORRECT:

Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by psychotic symptoms that last ≤ 1 month. This patient's psychotic symptoms started 7 months ago when she first started hearing voices.

D) CORRECT:

Schizoaffective disorder is a condition in which patients meet the clinical criteria for both schizophrenia and a major mood disorder. Patients must exhibit psychotic symptoms for ≥ 2 weeks in the absence of a major mood episode, and symptoms of a major mood disorder must be present for the majority of the duration of illness. This patient has auditory hallucinations that started 7 months ago and disorganized speech (thought-blocking; stopping in the middle of sentences), which fulfills the criteria for schizophrenia. She also has 5 of the diagnostic depressive symptoms (depressed mood, decreased appetite, insomnia, psychomotor slowing, inability to focus) that started 4 months ago, which fulfills the criteria for major depressive disorder.

To meet the criteria for schizophrenia, patients must have impaired function for ≥ 6 months with ≥ 2 of the following symptoms for ≥ 1 month: delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, disorganized behavior, and negative symptoms. One of the symptoms must be delusions, hallucinations, or disorganized speech.

E) INCORRECT:

Mood disorder with psychotic features is characterized by both psychotic symptoms and mood symptoms, which are seen in this patient. However, psychotic symptoms in this condition appear exclusively during manic or depressive episodes. This patient's psychotic symptoms started 7 months ago, when she first started hearing voices; her depressive symptoms started 4 months ago.

F) INCORRECT:

Individuals with schizotypal personality disorder typically have an eccentric appearance, hold odd or magical beliefs that are inconsistent with their cultural norms, and have few close relationships. Psychotic symptoms and mood symptoms are not features of this personality disorder.
questions.hint: This patient has both psychotic symptoms and mood symptoms.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician for a 6-week history of sleeping difficulties because she thinks that someone is watching her through security cameras. Her anxiety started 6 weeks ago when a neighbor installed security cameras outside their home. Ever since, she has felt that she is being monitored by security cameras throughout the city. She avoids going outside whenever possible and refuses to take the subway. Whenever she needs to leave the house, she wears large hats or hooded sweaters so that she cannot be recognized by the cameras. As soon as she arrives at her office or at home, she feels safer. She was recently promoted to the team manager of a small advertising agency. She takes no medications. On mental status examination, she is alert, oriented, and shows a normal range of affect. Urine toxicology screening is negative. The patient's symptoms are best described as which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Delirium can result in sleep disturbances, as seen in this patient. However, delirium manifests with a fluctuating state of confusion, altered consciousness, cognitive dysfunction, and perceptual disturbances, not the persistent disturbance of thought content seen here. Moreover, this patient does not have any risk factors for delirium (e.g., old age, hospitalization, infections, medications).

B) INCORRECT:

Agoraphobia is an anxiety disorder in which the individual fears being in situations that are perceived as difficult to escape from or in which it might be difficult to seek help. An individual with agoraphobia may prefer to remain homebound. However, this patient's aversion to going outside is due to the belief that she is being observed rather than the avoidance of specific situations.

C) CORRECT:

A delusion is a disturbance of thought content that is characterized by a fixed, false belief that is not derived from the individual's cultural or religious beliefs and cannot be changed by reasoning. This patient has a 6-week history of persecutory delusions and delusions of reference but functions normally at work and has no other psychotic symptoms. This is characteristic of delusional disorder. Delusions can also occur in patients with psychotic disorders (e.g., schizophrenia, mood disorder with psychotic features) and substance use disorders. Other types of delusions include delusions of grandeur, delusions of control, delusions of guilt, erotomanic delusions, and somatic delusions.

D) INCORRECT:

Derealization is a perceptual disturbance in which the individual feels detached from their surroundings and experiences the world as if it were a dream or movie. It occurs with panic attacks and dissociative disorders (e.g., depersonalization disorder, dissociative identity disorder). This patient has a disturbance of thought content, not a perceptual disturbance.

E) INCORRECT:

Avolition is characterized by decreased motivation to engage in purposeful activities. An individual with avolition may prefer to remain homebound. However, this patient's aversion to going outside is due to the belief that she is being observed rather than a lack of motivation.

F) INCORRECT:

A hallucination is a perceptual disturbance in which an individual perceives sensory stimuli despite the absence of an actual stimulus. For example, an individual experiencing a visual hallucination could start seeing objects that do not exist. This patient, who believes that the security cameras are being used to follow her, is not imagining the existence of the cameras but rather the purpose for which they are being used. This indicates a disturbance of thought content rather than perception.
questions.hint: This patient has a disorder of thought content.

questions.text: An 18-year-old previously healthy woman is brought to the physician by her father because she has been acting strangely for the past week. The patient's only brother died of leukemia 10 days ago. The father says that since the funeral a week ago, the patient has stayed in her brother's room most of the time and only joined the parents for breakfast and dinner. She has not gone to school since her brother's death. She eats very little and stays awake most of the night. The father reports that he has heard her talking in her brother's room even though she was alone and her phone was on the kitchen table. At the dinner table, she asked if she could have two extra plates for her imaginary friends, “Anna and Joseph”. The patient says that she misses her brother a lot and that she feels tired and sad all the time. She does not have nightmares or flashbacks and remembers details of her brother's last days and the funeral. She denies suicidal ideations or feelings of guilt. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use drugs recreationally. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. She appears calm and is attentive. Her speech is clear and organized. Her vital signs are within normal limits. During the examination, she suddenly turns to the side and says: “Yes, Joseph, this is a very good question, but wait until after the examination.” She then turns back to the physician and apologizes for the interruption. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adjustment disorder can occur in response to a traumatic life event and manifest with impaired social functioning and symptoms of depressed mood. However, affected individuals do not present with auditory hallucinations. Moreover, adjustment disorder is a diagnosis of exclusion, and this patient's symptoms are better explained by another psychological disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Insomnia and negative mood can be symptoms of acute stress disorder, which may be triggered by the death of a relative. However, this condition does not manifest with hallucinations. Moreover, affected individuals also present with intrusive symptoms (e.g., recurrent distressing memories/dreams about the traumatic event, flashbacks), dissociative symptoms (e.g., loss of memory regarding details of the event), active avoidance (i.e., avoidance of external reminders, memories, thoughts, and feelings related to the event), and other symptoms related to arousal (e.g., irritable behavior, hypervigilance).

C) INCORRECT:

Major depressive disorder with psychotic features manifests with depressed mood, insomnia, fatigue, appetite changes, and psychotic symptoms such as auditory hallucinations. The diagnostic criteria for this condition require the symptoms to last ≥ 2 weeks, so this patient does not meet the diagnostic criteria for this condition yet. If her symptoms last an additional week, this would be the most likely diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Normal bereavement can manifest with sleep disturbances, depressed mood, and auditory hallucinations following the loss of a loved one. However, normal bereavement does not usually impair daily functioning, and this patient's isolation and inability to go to school suggest impaired social functioning. Moreover, while auditory hallucinations of the deceased are possible in normal bereavement, hallucinations unrelated to the deceased suggest a different diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Pathological grief manifests with functional impairment in response to the death of a loved one, and affected individuals can present with features of depressed mood and hallucinations. However, while auditory hallucinations of the deceased are possible in pathological grief, unrelated hallucinations are not. Moreover, pathological grief is usually diagnosed when the grieving process persists beyond 12 months, and this patient's symptoms started only one week ago.

F) INCORRECT:

Schizoaffective disorder manifests with psychotic symptoms and mood symptoms. However, while this patient only presents with auditory hallucinations, the diagnostic criteria for this condition require the presence of ≥ 2 of the following psychotic symptoms: delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, negative symptoms, and grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior. Additionally, diagnostic criteria for this condition also require the presence of psychotic symptoms without mood symptoms for ≥ 2 weeks; this patient has not had any period without mood symptoms.

G) INCORRECT:

Schizophreniform disorder manifests with psychotic symptoms such as auditory hallucinations and impaired functioning. However, this patient's only psychotic symptom is auditory hallucination, and diagnostic criteria for this condition require the presence of ≥ 2 of the following psychotic symptoms: delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, negative symptoms, and grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior. Additionally, symptoms must last for 1–6 months, and this patient's symptoms started only one week ago.

H) CORRECT:

This patient's 1-week history of auditory hallucinations after her brother's funeral is suggestive of a brief psychotic disorder, which is characterized by positive psychotic symptoms (e.g., delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech) that are typically triggered by a stressful life event and last > 1 day and ≤ 1 month. The onset of symptoms is usually sudden (without a prodrome) and the functional impairment can be severe. After the episode, individuals gradually return to the premorbid state. Although this patient currently meets the diagnostic criteria for this condition, psychiatric diagnoses are dynamic, changing depending on the duration of symptoms and whether new symptoms arise. Since this patient also presents with depressed mood, insomnia, decreased appetite, and fatigue, if her symptoms persist for another week, the main diagnostic challenge would be to distinguish a brief psychotic disorder from a major depressive disorder with psychotic features.
questions.hint: This patient presents with auditory hallucinations that are unrelated to the deceased.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his sister after she stopped him from jumping off the balcony of his high-rise apartment building. The patient says, “I had to listen to the voices. They finally told me to fly away.” During the past 5 months, he has had a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss due to decreased appetite and lack of energy. Two months ago, he was fired from his job because he was frequently absent without notice and has since spent most of his time sleeping in his apartment. He says he doesn't care that he lost his job because, according to the patient, he felt “inadequate and stupid” anyway. He used to be an avid chess player but stopped because he could no longer concentrate when he played. He reports that he first started hearing voices 7 months ago and that they started giving him instructions about 3 weeks ago. He appears thin and disheveled. On mental status examination, he has a depressed mood and flat affect. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. Toxicology screening of the urine is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mood disorder with psychotic features is characterized by the presence of both mood symptoms (e.g., depressive symptoms) and psychotic symptoms (e.g., hallucinations). Psychotic symptoms manifest exclusively during the depressive episode. This patient's auditory hallucinations started 7 months ago, and his depressive symptoms started 5 months ago. The presence of psychotic symptoms for a period of time in the absence of a mood disorder rules out a diagnosis of mood disorder with psychotic features.

B) INCORRECT:

Schizotypal personality disorder is characterized by odd and eccentric behavior with magical thinking and social anxiety. Magical thinking is the attribution of causal relationships where there is no evidence for their existence (e.g., that the number 13 causes bad luck or that a certain gesture can ward off evil). In contrast, this patient has auditory hallucinations in combination with features of major depressive disorder (e.g., feeling of worthlessness, hypersomnia, depressed mood), which are not features of schizotypal personality disorder.

C) CORRECT:

Schizoaffective disorder is characterized by features of schizophrenia and a mood disorder (major depressive disorder or bipolar disorder). To make the diagnosis, psychotic features must be present for ≥ 2 weeks in the absence of mood symptoms and mood symptoms must be present for the majority of the total duration of the illness. Schizophrenic features in this patient include hallucinations (hearing voices) and negative symptoms (flat affect); his hallucinations have been present for 7 months. He also has depressive symptoms that began 5 months ago, including depressed mood, weight change due to appetite change, low energy, hypersomnia, feeling of worthlessness, and diminished concentration.

See “Psychotic disorders” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by psychotic symptoms that last between 1 day and 1 month. However, this patient's auditory hallucinations started 7 months ago.

E) INCORRECT:

Schizophreniform disorder is characterized by psychotic symptoms that last for 1–6 months. However, this patient's auditory hallucinations started 7 months ago. Moreover, patients with schizophreniform disorder do not have significant mood symptoms; this patient's depressed mood, weight loss due to appetite change, low energy, hypersomnia, feeling of worthlessness, and diminished concentration are features of major depressive disorder.

F) INCORRECT:

This patient has features of schizophrenia, including hallucinations (hearing voices) and negative symptoms (flat affect). However, he also has features of major depressive disorder, including depressed mood, weight change due to appetite change, low energy, hypersomnia, feeling of worthlessness, and diminished concentration. The combination of symptoms of schizophrenia and a concurrent mood disorder indicates a different diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is characterized by the presence of both psychotic and mood symptoms.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman is brought to the office by her father because of a change in her behavior over the past 8 months. The father says that his daughter has become increasingly withdrawn; she has not answered any phone calls or visited her family and friends. The patient says that she has to stay at home because a foreign intelligence service is monitoring her. She thinks that they are using a magnetic field to read her mind. Mental status exam shows disjointed and perseverative thinking. She is anxious and has a flat affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Schizophrenia commonly presents with a prodrome of negative symptoms (e.g., disorganized thinking, social withdrawal), followed by positive symptoms (e.g., hallucinations, delusions, bizarre behavior). The diagnosis requires that these symptoms have been present for ≥ 1 month and that some sign of illness has persisted for at least 6 months. Based on this patient's symptoms of social withdrawal and paranoid delusion, which have been present for around 8 months, she has schizophrenia.

B) INCORRECT:

Delusional disorder is characterized by fixed, odd beliefs that are not consistent with cultural norms. This patient's functional impairment (e.g., staying at home, avoiding family and friends) is not consistent with delusional disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Paranoid personality disorder is characterized by irrational distrust towards others and the misconception that other people have malicious intentions. However, this woman has evidence of paranoid delusions (e.g., she's convinced she's being monitored using a magnetic field) and disorganized thought process, neither of which are characteristic of paranoid personality disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Schizoid personality disorder is also characterized by odd and eccentric behavior, flat affect, and a lack of close friendships. However, this patient's severe social withdrawal and paranoid delusions are not typical of schizoid personality disorder. Additionally, personality disorders typically begin in early adulthood and remain stable over time, while the onset of this patient's symptoms was fairly recent.

E) INCORRECT:

Schizophreniform disorder is an important diagnosis to consider in this patient, as it can also present with paranoid delusions and social withdrawal. However, schizophreniform disorder is only diagnosed if the symptoms have been present for less than 6 months.
questions.hint: Patients with this disease can also develop catatonia.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a change in his personality. The mother reports that over the past 7 months her son has become increasingly withdrawn; he has not answered any phone calls or visited his family and friends. He used to meet with friends at least once a week. The patient says that he cannot leave the house because aliens are watching him and are “stealing his thoughts”. He used to smoke cannabis occasionally but quit 1 year ago. On mental status examination, it is impossible to follow the patient's sequence of thoughts. He is anxious and has a flat affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Schizotypal personality disorder is also characterized by eccentric behavior, which may include magical thinking (e.g., inventing causal relationships between unrelated events). However, such thinking is rarely of the bizarre type. Furthermore, negative symptoms such as social withdrawal, agitation, and fleeting thoughts are less severe than those seen in this patient. Additionally, personality disorders are stable over time, whereas this patient's symptoms started only 7 months ago.

B) INCORRECT:

Mood disorder with psychotic features would require a diagnosis of mania or major depressive disorder (MDD). Although flat affect and social withdrawal can also be seen in MDD, this patient exhibits no feelings of worthlessness or guilt, depressed mood, suicidal ideation, weight change due to appetite change or sleep disturbances. As such, he does not meet enough of the criteria for a diagnosis of MDD.

C) INCORRECT:

Schizoaffective disorder can cause symptoms similar to those seen in this patient. However, the diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder requires a major mood disorder (e.g., major depressive disorder; MDD) to be present. Even though flat affect and social withdrawal can also be seen in MDD, this patient exhibits no feelings of worthlessness or guilt, depressed mood, suicidal ideation, weight change due to appetite change or sleep disturbances. As such, he does not meet enough of the criteria for a diagnosis of MDD.

D) INCORRECT:

Substance-induced psychosis (e.g., from cannabis use) can also manifest with bizarre behavior, delusions, and a state of anxiety or agitation, as seen in this patient. However, this patient stopped smoking cannabis a year ago and does not report using any other substance that could result in substance-induced psychosis.

E) CORRECT:

Schizophrenia typically manifests with a prodrome of negative symptoms (e.g., social withdrawal, flat affect) that precedes the positive psychotic symptoms, such as delusions (e.g., bizarre thoughts of aliens watching him) and disorganized speech. The diagnosis also requires that these symptoms have been present for ≥ 1 month and that some sign of illness must persist for at least 6 months.
questions.hint: Frequent use of cannabis during adolescence is a possible trigger for this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the office for a 6-week history of sleeping difficulties because she thinks that someone is watching her through security cameras. Her anxiety started 6 weeks ago when a neighbor installed security cameras outside their home. Ever since, she has felt that she is being monitored by security cameras throughout the city and avoids going outside whenever possible. Whenever she needs to leave the house she wears large hats or hooded sweaters so that she cannot be recognized by the cameras. When she arrives at her office or home she feels safer. She was recently promoted to manager at work. On mental status examination, she is alert, oriented, and shows a normal range of affect. Urine toxicology screening is negative. The patient's symptoms are best described as which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Delirium can result in sleep disturbances, as seen in this patient. However, delirium manifests with a fluctuating state of confusion, altered consciousness, cognitive dysfunction, and perceptual disturbances, not the persistent disturbance of thought content seen here. Moreover, this patient does not have any risk factors for delirium (e.g., old age, hospitalization, infections, medications).

B) INCORRECT:

Agoraphobia is an anxiety disorder in which the individual fears being in situations that are perceived as difficult to escape from or in which it might be difficult to seek help. An individual with agoraphobia may prefer to remain homebound, as seen here. However, this patient's aversion to going outside is due to the belief that she is being observed rather than the avoidance of specific situations.

C) CORRECT:

A delusion is a disturbance of thought content that is characterized by a fixed, false belief that is not derived from the individual's cultural or religious beliefs and cannot be changed by reasoning. This patient has a 6-week history of persecutory delusions and delusions of reference but functions normally at work and has no other psychotic symptoms. This is characteristic of delusional disorder. Delusions can also occur in patients with psychotic disorders (e.g., schizophrenia, mood disorder with psychotic features), and substance use disorders. Other types of delusions include delusions of grandeur, delusions of control, delusions of guilt, erotomanic delusions, and somatic delusions.

D) INCORRECT:

Derealization is a perceptual disturbance in which the individual feels detached from their surroundings and experiences the world as if it were a dream or movie. It occurs with panic attacks and dissociative disorders (e.g., depersonalization disorder, dissociative identity disorder). This patient has a disturbance of thought content, not a perceptual disturbance.

E) INCORRECT:

Avolition is characterized by decreased motivation to engage in purposeful activities. An individual with avolition may prefer to remain homebound, as seen here. However, this patient's aversion to going outside is due to the belief that she is being observed rather than a lack of motivation.
questions.hint: This patient has a disorder of thought content.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old accountant is brought to the hospital by her spouse after locking herself in the bathroom, claiming that voices from the TV were instructing her to stay away from all electronics. These behaviors began suddenly one week ago after learning about her mother’s severe illness. She has no prior psychiatric history and denies substance use. Her orientation is intact.
Which of the following diagnoses best explains her condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Delusional disorder involves non-bizarre delusions without prominent hallucinations. This patient experiences auditory hallucinations, which are not typical of delusional disorder. The sudden onset after her mother's illness and the presence of hallucinations indicate an acute psychotic episode rather than the chronic course of delusional disorder.

B) CORRECT:

Brief psychotic disorder manifests with sudden onset of psychotic symptoms, such as hallucinations and delusions, often following a significant stressor. This patient developed auditory hallucinations after learning about her mother's severe illness, illustrating the role of an acute stressor. The symptoms have persisted for one week, aligning with the disorder's duration criterion of at least one day but less than one month. Her intact orientation and lack of prior psychiatric history further support this diagnosis, indicating a stress-induced, transient psychosis.

Key learning point: Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by the sudden onset of psychotic symptoms lasting more than a day but less than a month, often following a significant stressor, with a full return to pre-morbid functioning.

C) INCORRECT:

Schizophreniform disorder requires psychotic symptoms to persist for at least one month but less than six months. This patient's symptoms have been present for only one week, which does not meet the duration criterion. The sudden onset following an acute stressor and her preserved orientation also suggest a more transient condition than schizophreniform disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Schizophrenia requires chronic psychotic symptoms persisting for at least six months, with a minimum of one month of active-phase symptoms. This patient's symptoms began abruptly one week ago, following a significant stressor, and lack the chronicity and functional decline typical of schizophrenia. Her intact orientation and short symptom duration further differentiate her condition from schizophrenia.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department by her sister after refusing to leave her house for the past four days. She reports hearing voices commanding her to perform repetitive tasks, such as brushing her teeth every hour, and believes a secret government agency implanted a device in her ear. She has been increasingly restless, has had little sleep, and exhibits disorganized speech. She denies any history of mood episodes or substance use.
Which of the following diagnoses best explains her presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dissociative identity disorder involves two or more distinct personality states and significant memory gaps. Auditory experiences in this disorder are internal dissociative processes, not true psychotic hallucinations. The patient lacks distinct identities or amnesia, and the presence of delusions and command hallucinations suggests a psychotic disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Borderline personality disorder features instability in relationships, self-image, and affect, with impulsivity. Transient psychotic-like experiences can occur but are brief and stress-induced. The patient's persistent hallucinations and delusions indicate a primary psychotic process, not the transient states seen in borderline personality disorder.

C) CORRECT:

The patient exhibits acute onset of psychotic symptoms, including auditory hallucinations, delusional beliefs, and disorganized speech. These symptoms align with brief psychotic disorder, characterized by sudden psychotic episodes lasting at least one day but less than one month, with a return to baseline functioning. The absence of mood episodes or substance use supports a primary psychotic process. The duration and nature of symptoms help differentiate brief psychotic disorder from other psychiatric conditions with longer-lasting psychosis or affective disturbances.

Key learning point: Psychosis is characterized by symptoms such as delusions, hallucinations, lack of insight, and disorganized thinking, distinguishing it from neurosis, personality disorders, and dissociative conversion disorders.

D) INCORRECT:

Somatic symptom disorder involves excessive focus on physical symptoms with disproportionate thoughts and behaviors. The patient's auditory hallucinations, delusions, and disorganized speech indicate a psychotic process, not a preoccupation with bodily symptoms. The psychotic symptoms are not characteristic of somatic symptom disorder.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his roommate due to increasingly odd behavior over the past year. He believes the government is watching him through the television and that a light bulb in his room transmits divine signals. He frequently whispers back to “higher authorities” he believes contact him. He has had difficulty maintaining a job and has withdrawn from friends. Neurological and laboratory evaluations are normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Schizophreniform disorder is characterized by schizophrenia-like symptoms lasting at least 1 month but less than 6 months. This patient's symptoms have persisted for over a year, exceeding the duration criteria for schizophreniform disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Schizoaffective disorder involves both psychotic symptoms and significant mood symptoms occurring concurrently. This patient shows psychotic features, such as paranoid delusions and auditory hallucinations, but lacks any reported mood symptoms, such as depression or mania, making schizoaffective disorder less likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Delusional disorder involves non-bizarre delusions without prominent hallucinations or disorganized behavior, and individuals typically maintain daily functioning. This patient has bizarre delusions and auditory hallucinations, along with significant social and occupational dysfunction, which are inconsistent with delusional disorder.

D) CORRECT:

Schizophrenia manifests with persistent psychotic symptoms, including delusions and hallucinations, lasting at least 6 months, with an active phase of at least 1 month. This patient exhibits bizarre delusions, such as believing the government monitors him and a light bulb transmits divine signals, and auditory hallucinations, evidenced by whispering back to 'higher authorities.' The decline in social and occupational functioning further supports the diagnosis. Normal neurological and laboratory evaluations help exclude other etiologies, aligning with current diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia.

Key learning point: Delusions, such as believing in government surveillance through the TV and divine communication through a light bulb, are characteristic of schizophrenia, a disorder involving psychotic symptoms.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents with an 8-month history of increasing withdrawal from friends and family. He reports regularly hearing a voice criticizing his daily actions and ideas. He also believes his roommate can perceive every thought in his head, though he cannot explain how. His mood has been stable, and there is no known substance use. Physical examination is normal. He has difficulty maintaining a coherent conversation.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Schizophreniform disorder presents with symptoms similar to schizophrenia but lasts at least 1 month and less than 6 months. This patient's symptoms have persisted for 8 months, exceeding the duration criteria for schizophreniform disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Schizoaffective disorder involves both psychotic symptoms and significant mood disturbances, such as major depressive or manic episodes, occurring concurrently. This patient has stable mood without depressive or manic symptoms, which does not meet the criteria for schizoaffective disorder.

C) CORRECT:

Schizophrenia manifests with chronic symptoms such as delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, and negative symptoms persisting for at least 6 months. This patient exhibits auditory hallucinations, delusions of thought broadcasting, and disorganized speech, indicating positive symptoms. His social withdrawal reflects negative symptoms. These features, along with the 8-month duration, align with schizophrenia. The disorder involves dysregulation in dopaminergic and glutamatergic neurotransmission and often begins in young adulthood.

Key learning point: Auditory hallucinations and thought broadcasting are characteristic symptoms of schizophrenia, a psychotic disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by sudden onset of psychotic symptoms lasting more than one day but less than one month, followed by a full recovery. This patient's symptoms have persisted for 8 months, far exceeding the duration criteria for brief psychotic disorder.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man presents with 7 months of gradually worsening auditory hallucinations, paranoid delusions about coworkers, disorganized speech, poor self-care, and social withdrawal. He denies depressed mood or manic episodes, and there is no known substance use. His mother confirms these behaviors began around that time. Physical examination shows poor hygiene but is otherwise normal.
Which of the following diagnoses best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient presents with auditory hallucinations, paranoid delusions, disorganized speech, and negative symptoms such as poor self-care and social withdrawal. These symptoms align with the diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia, which requires at least 6 months of symptoms. The absence of mood disturbances and the presence of persistent psychotic symptoms further support this diagnosis. The combination of positive and negative symptoms over a prolonged period is characteristic of schizophrenia.

Key learning point: Schizophrenia is characterized by delusions, hallucinations, and disorganized behavior, with symptoms typically persisting for at least 6 months.

B) INCORRECT:

Brief psychotic disorder involves sudden onset of psychotic symptoms lasting from 1 day to less than 1 month, with a full return to premorbid functioning. This patient's symptoms have persisted for 7 months, far exceeding the duration criterion for brief psychotic disorder, making it an inappropriate diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Schizophreniform disorder shares symptoms with schizophrenia but lasts between 1 and 6 months. This patient's symptoms have persisted for 7 months, exceeding the duration for schizophreniform disorder. The longer duration of symptoms is a key factor in ruling out this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Schizoaffective disorder involves both psychotic symptoms and significant mood symptoms (depressive or manic) for a substantial portion of the illness. This patient denies mood disturbances, such as depression or mania, which are essential for diagnosing schizoaffective disorder. The lack of mood symptoms makes this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: You are seeing a 29-year-old woman who is brought to your clinic by her father due to an 8-month history of behavioral changes. Her father reports that she has become increasingly withdrawn and has stopped answering phone calls or visiting family and friends. The patient states that she must stay at home because a foreign intelligence service is monitoring her and believes they are using a magnetic field to read her mind. On mental status examination, her thinking is disjointed and perseverative. She appears anxious and has a flat affect. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Schizophrenia commonly presents with a prodrome of negative symptoms (e.g., disorganized thinking, social withdrawal), followed by positive symptoms (e.g., hallucinations, delusions, bizarre behavior). The diagnosis requires that these symptoms have been present for ≥ 1 month and that some sign of illness has persisted for at least 6 months. Based on this patient's symptoms of social withdrawal and paranoid delusion, which have been present for around 8 months, she has schizophrenia.

Key learning point: Schizophrenia is diagnosed by at least 6 months of persistent symptoms including social withdrawal, disorganized thinking, and psychotic features such as delusions or hallucinations.

B) INCORRECT:

Paranoid personality disorder is characterized by irrational distrust towards others and the misconception that other people have malicious intentions. However, this woman has evidence of paranoid delusions (e.g., she's convinced she's being monitored using a magnetic field) and disorganized thought process, neither of which are characteristic of paranoid personality disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Schizoid personality disorder is also characterized by odd and eccentric behavior, flat affect, and a lack of close friendships. However, this patient's severe social withdrawal and paranoid delusions are not typical of schizoid personality disorder. Additionally, personality disorders typically begin in early adulthood and remain stable over time, while the onset of this patient's symptoms was fairly recent.

D) INCORRECT:

Delusional disorder is characterized by fixed, odd beliefs that are not consistent with cultural norms. This patient's functional impairment (e.g., staying at home, avoiding family and friends) is not consistent with delusional disorder.

E) INCORRECT:

Schizophreniform disorder is an important diagnosis to consider in this patient, as it can also present with paranoid delusions and social withdrawal. However, schizophreniform disorder is only diagnosed if the symptoms have been present for less than 6 months.
questions.hint: Patients with this disease can also develop catatonia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of anxiety that strangers are poisoning her food. Her anxiety worsened after witnessing a man choking at a restaurant 3 weeks ago. She states, “They were trying to get me, but they made a mistake.” She refuses to eat any food she does not prepare herself and keeps her packed lunch close to her at work at all times. She is able to complete all of her work tasks without difficulty. On mental status examination, her thought processes and speech are organized. She denies auditory, visual, or tactile hallucinations. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A brief psychotic disorder can manifest with delusions and ideas of reference and typically develops after an acute stressor (e.g., seeing a man choking). However, this condition lasts < 1 month; this patient's symptoms started 2 months ago.

B) INCORRECT:

Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) manifests with anxiety about various issues (e.g., poor performance at school, fear of being involved in an accident) but does not typically manifest with delusions or ideas of reference. Moreover, GAD often results in the development of somatic symptoms such as fatigue, irritability, insomnia, and/or muscle tension, and the symptoms of anxiety must be present for ≥ 6 months before this condition can be diagnosed.

C) CORRECT:

Delusional disorder is characterized by one or more delusions that last ≥ 1 month and are not the result of other conditions (e.g., schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, substance use disorder). This patient has a fixed belief that she will be poisoned and ideas of reference (she interprets a man choking as an attempt to poison her). Function in individuals with delusional disorder is otherwise unimpaired; this woman is still able to function at work, and her thought process, speech, memory, and attention are intact.

Key learning point: Delusional disorder is characterized by one or more persistent, non-bizarre delusions lasting at least one month, with otherwise unimpaired functioning and no other prominent psychotic symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Individuals with schizotypal personality disorder can be suspicious, anxious, and have ideas of reference. However, patients with this personality disorder typically have an eccentric appearance, hold odd or magical beliefs that are inconsistent with their cultural norms, and have few close relationships. Well-formed delusions (e.g., this patient's persistent belief that she will be poisoned) are uncommon.

E) INCORRECT:

Schizophreniform disorder typically manifests with delusions and ideas of reference. However, delusions in this condition are usually bizarre (i.e., clearly implausible, not derived from ordinary life experiences, and/or not understandable). This patient lacks other features of schizophreniform disorder such as auditory hallucinations, disorganized speech, and catatonia.
questions.hint: The key feature of this patient's condition is an excessive preoccupation with a distinct theme that can lead to odd behavior. In areas unrelated to this theme, behavior is typically normal.

questions.text: You are seeing a 26-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of 6 weeks of unusual and agitated behavior. He believes that the National Security Agency is spying on him and controlling his mind. He stopped going to work 4 weeks ago to focus on developing an invention to block mind control. His wife reports that he has lost his job and withdrawn from all social contact. On mental status examination, he is suspicious, displays marked psychomotor agitation, has disorganized speech, and a labile affect. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Schizoaffective disorder is characterized by a continuous illness episode in which features of a major mood episode (depressive, manic, or mixed) occur alongside psychotic symptoms that meet the criteria for schizophrenia. By definition, mood disorder symptoms must be present for most of the time. This patient does not meet the criteria for a major mood episode.

B) CORRECT:

Schizophreniform disorder is a clinical diagnosis that is made using the same diagnostic criteria as schizophrenia. This condition is diagnosed in patients who present with symptoms of schizophrenia (e.g., delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, negative symptoms) that last for at least 1 month but less than 6 months. If diagnosed before recovery, the term “schizophreniform disorder (provisional)” is used. If symptoms persist for ≥ 6 months, the diagnosis must be changed to schizophrenia. About one-third of patients recover while the other two-thirds develop schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder.

Key learning point: Schizophreniform disorder is diagnosed when schizophrenia-like symptoms last at least 1 month but less than 6 months.

C) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's clinical presentation is consistent with schizophrenia, psychotic symptoms must last ≥ 6 months in order to make this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Although this patient presents with features consistent with paranoid personality disorder (excessive distrust and suspicion of others), his symptoms only developed 6 weeks ago. Personality disorders typically arise during adolescence, making another diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has features consistent with delusional disorder (delusions, paranoia), he also presents with psychotic symptoms (disorganized speech and behavior) and social withdrawal (i.e., markedly impaired social functioning), both of which are inconsistent with delusional disorder.
questions.hint: This patient presents with acute agitation in combination with disorganized speech and behavior following a 6-week history of delusions and social withdrawal.

questions.text: You are seeing a 23-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department by his mother due to a change in his personality. His mother reports that over the past 7 months, he has become increasingly withdrawn and has not answered phone calls or visited family and friends, whereas he previously met with friends at least once a week. He states that he cannot leave the house because aliens are watching him and “stealing his thoughts.” He has a history of occasional cannabis use but stopped 1 year ago. On mental status examination, his sequence of thoughts is impossible to follow. He appears anxious and has a flat affect. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Schizoaffective disorder can cause symptoms similar to those seen in this patient. However, the diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder requires a major mood disorder (e.g., major depressive disorder; MDD) to be present. Even though flat affect and social withdrawal can also be seen in MDD, this patient exhibits no feelings of worthlessness or guilt, depressed mood, suicidal ideation, weight change due to appetite change or sleep disturbances. As such, he does not meet enough of the criteria for a diagnosis of MDD.

B) CORRECT:

Schizophrenia typically manifests with a prodrome of negative symptoms (e.g., social withdrawal, flat affect) that precedes the positive psychotic symptoms, such as delusions (e.g., bizarre thoughts of aliens watching him) and disorganized speech. The diagnosis also requires that these symptoms have been present for ≥ 1 month and that some sign of illness must persist for at least 6 months.

Key learning point: Schizophrenia is diagnosed by at least 6 months of persistent symptoms, including negative symptoms (e.g., social withdrawal) and positive symptoms (e.g., delusions, disorganized speech).

C) INCORRECT:

Mood disorder with psychotic features would require a diagnosis of mania or major depressive disorder (MDD). Although flat affect and social withdrawal can also be seen in MDD, this patient exhibits no feelings of worthlessness or guilt, depressed mood, suicidal ideation, weight change due to appetite change or sleep disturbances. As such, he does not meet enough of the criteria for a diagnosis of MDD.

D) INCORRECT:

Schizotypal personality disorder is also characterized by eccentric behavior, which may include magical thinking (e.g., inventing causal relationships between unrelated events). However, such thinking is rarely of the bizarre type. Furthermore, negative symptoms such as social withdrawal, agitation, and fleeting thoughts are less severe than those seen in this patient. Additionally, personality disorders are stable over time, whereas this patient's symptoms started only 7 months ago.

E) INCORRECT:

Substance-induced psychosis (e.g., from cannabis use) can also manifest with bizarre behavior, delusions, and a state of anxiety or agitation, as seen in this patient. However, this patient stopped smoking cannabis a year ago and does not report using any other substance that could result in substance-induced psychosis.
questions.hint: Frequent use of cannabis during adolescence is a possible trigger for this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the ED with a 3-day history of believing that his neighbors are monitoring him through his television and hearing voices commenting on his actions. He has no past psychiatric history, denies substance use, and takes no medications. Vital signs are BP, 125/78; P, 88; R, 16; T, 37.2°C (99.0°F); oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. Physical examination shows no focal neurological deficits or systemic abnormalities. Mental status examination shows he is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Which additional clinical finding would most strongly support a diagnosis of secondary psychosis?

choices.text: Normal vital signs and physical examination

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An alert and oriented mental status is more typical of primary psychosis. Secondary psychosis often manifests with altered mental status, disorientation, or fluctuating consciousness.

B) INCORRECT:

The absence of prior psychiatric history can occur in both primary and secondary psychosis. While first-episode psychosis warrants evaluation for secondary causes, this finding alone does not differentiate between primary and secondary etiologies.

C) INCORRECT:

Normal vital signs and physical examination findings are more consistent with primary psychosis. Secondary psychosis often manifests with abnormal vital signs or systemic symptoms reflecting the underlying medical condition.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Visual hallucinations are more commonly associated with secondary psychosis, particularly due to medical conditions or substance use. The presence of visual hallucinations, especially when concurrent with auditory hallucinations, should raise suspicion for an underlying medical cause.

E) INCORRECT:

Auditory hallucinations are more commonly associated with primary psychosis. While they can occur in secondary psychosis, their presence alone does not support a secondary cause.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 6-day history of progressive agitation, insomnia, and paranoid thoughts. She reports seeing threatening figures in her peripheral vision and believes coworkers are monitoring her activities. Her roommate mentions she stopped taking her prescribed medications 2 weeks ago but denies recent substance use. On examination, she appears anxious and hypervigilant but maintains good eye contact. Vital signs are normal. She is oriented to person, place, and time. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate psychiatric consultation for medication adjustment
Obtain comprehensive metabolic panel and thyroid function tests
Perform urine toxicology screening and drug levels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient does not have acute agitation requiring immediate pharmacological intervention. She maintains good eye contact and orientation, suggesting she is not severely agitated. Agitation management should be reserved for patients whose behavior poses a danger to themselves or others.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's presentation is consistent with primary psychosis, likely exacerbated by medication discontinuation. The classic psychotic symptoms (paranoid delusions, visual hallucinations) with normal vital signs and orientation distinguish primary psychosis from substance-induced psychosis. Psychiatric consultation is recommended for primary psychosis management and medication adjustment.

C) INCORRECT:

While metabolic and endocrine disorders can cause secondary psychosis, this patient's history of stopping prescribed medications and the 6-day timeline suggest primary psychosis exacerbation rather than a new medical condition. Abnormal vital signs are more commonly seen in secondary psychosis.

D) INCORRECT:

The roommate's denial of substance use, the patient's normal vital signs, and the temporal relationship with medication discontinuation make substance-induced psychosis less likely. Substance-induced psychosis typically manifests with intoxication or withdrawal symptoms and abnormal vital signs.

E) INCORRECT:

Brain imaging is not routinely indicated unless there are focal neurological signs, seizures, or evidence of head trauma.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute confusion, visual hallucinations, and paranoid delusions that began 2 days ago. His wife reports he has no psychiatric history. Vital signs reveal temperature 38.1°C, blood pressure 160/95 mmHg, heart rate 110 bpm, and respiratory rate 22/min. Physical examination shows disorientation to time and place with a fluctuating level of consciousness. Basic metabolic panel reveals sodium 128 mEq/L and glucose 380 mg/dL. After initial stabilization, what is the most appropriate disposition?

choices.text: Admit to medical ward with psychiatry consultation
Discharge home with outpatient psychiatry follow-up

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient demonstrates clear features of secondary psychosis including advanced age, sudden onset, abnormal vital signs, fluctuating mental state, visual hallucinations, and metabolic abnormalities. Secondary psychosis requires treatment of the underlying medical conditions with psychiatry consultation for management of psychotic symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Outpatient management is inappropriate for secondary psychosis because patients frequently require inpatient management until their mental status returns to baseline. The presence of abnormal vital signs, fluctuating consciousness, and metabolic abnormalities indicates secondary psychosis requiring medical treatment. 

C) INCORRECT:

Direct psychiatric admission would miss the underlying medical conditions causing the psychosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Crisis intervention centers are not equipped to manage the complex medical issues causing secondary psychosis.

E) INCORRECT:

While the patient requires medical admission, the clinical presentation does not indicate the need for intensive care level monitoring.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with schizophrenia presents with his roommate reporting 3 days of increasing confusion and agitation. The patient normally manages well on stable risperidone therapy. On examination, he appears disoriented to place and time, has a coarse tremor, and has a temperature of 38.6°C (101.5°F) and heart rate of 110/minute. His roommate reports that the patient recently started working at a chemical plant and has been complaining of headaches and nausea. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer haloperidol and discharge with psychiatric follow-up
Obtain urine drug screen and increase risperidone dose
Transfer to psychiatric facility after medical clearance
